content.title: Culture and shopping along the Rue des Arts

introduction.small: Toulon's city centre has seen a rebirth with the opening of the Rue des Arts in 2017. Art galleries, workshops and designer boutiques have gathered on this renovated pedestrian street.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Culture and shopping along the Rue des Arts

paragraphs.text:
With its galleries, workshops and designers, the Rue des Arts in Toulon is aptly named, to say the least. Formerly "Rue du Canon", rechristened "Rue Pierre-Sémard" in tribute to the union fighter shot by German troops in 1942, it has finally been entirely renovated within the grand project of restoring the whole city centre. The concept here is to rehabilitate and breathe in new life to the public space of this historic neighbourhood, using art themes. Today, lovers of "all things beautiful" take a stroll and attend a contemporary photography exhibition at Galerie 15, discover surprising Naïve art at Créations tropicales and visit artist workshops at Les Frangines. You only need to walk around and look up to experience open-air galleries as various photographs are actually exhibited right in the street. As for shopaholics, they have not been left out and will find various designer boutiques along the street, like By LMS for fashion items and French-made bedding, or AV Bijoux for jewellery like earrings, necklaces and artisan bracelets. On Thursday nights, the Rue des Arts lights up with concerts and art classes, all free of charge.

Rue des Arts
83000 Toulon

https://www.ruedesarts.fr

content.title: Santa Rosalia, Mexican tacos with an organic and local twist

introduction.small: In Toulon, Santa Rosalia explores the one-of-a-kind Mexican street food with organic and local products, served in a vintage urban saloon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Santa Rosalia, Mexican tacos with an organic and local twist

paragraphs.text:
Seating at long clear wooden table under a Frida Kahlo painting, lovers of Mexican food could feel just like being in a real taqueria, those taco-specialised establishments that also serve a few other Mexican dishes. And yet, on the terrace filled with coloured-legged chairs, it is the unmistakable Mediterranean sun that shines. Santa Rosalia has imported the taqueria concept onto the streets of Toulon, giving it a twist by using organic and local products.

Inside, the vintage decoration mixes with retro furniture and walls expose old stones and concrete in a lovely mix of ancient and modern tones. Behind the counter, the duo of Emmanuel and Henri means business in the kitchen. They cook tacos by the minute, following seasonal recipes. On the tight menu, which changes on a daily basis, you will find various taco offerings - including a rice-based one in lieu of the taco shell for those who like to eat with a fork - as well as tostadas and more classic fare, but always according to the principle of sourcing the best products. Flour from Bras, Correns wine, veal from the Alps, regional vegetables, locally brewed beer… even the crockery is made in France!

Santa Rosalia

content.title: Resto'25, fine Mediterranean dining

introduction.small: A few steps away from the port, Resto'25 presents a minimalist menu, based on fresh products in an elegant and subdued atmosphere.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Resto'25, fine Mediterranean dining

paragraphs.text:
With its flecked velvet chairs laid under geometrical lights, this restaurant stands out in Toulon's city centre. On the outside, a blackboard presents the daily specials. Moreover, the menu changes regularly and puts fresh, local and seasonal products in the spotlight. At Resto'25, no frills expected in the plate. Cuisine is sober, refined and to the point, with Mediterranean inspirations. Some classics regularly come forward, like the octopus in garlic and parsley sauce, the lobster (or half-lobster if you want) grilled in rosemary, a vegetarian savoury crumble and the pork leg, slow-cooked for seven hours and served with mashed sweet potatoes and vegetables from the market. These fine dishes are best enjoyed on the terrace when the sun is up, or at the counter for a bistro feel. There is something for every generation at Resto'25!

content.title: La Maison de la Photographie, a local institution

introduction.small: Discover the work of local and international artists at the Toulon House of Photography.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Maison de la Photographie, a local institution

paragraphs.text:
Located in a former Turkish bath, the Maison de la Photographie has retained the building's original circular structure to remain authentic. Opened in 2002 in the heart of the Old Town, it exhibits works by famous photographs, such as Robert Doisneau, Henri Cartier-Bresson, Raymond Depardon and Édouard Boubat. In the temporary exhibition gallery, you can discover "plastician", humanist and photojournalist photographs.
Amongst a collection of more than 400 works exhibited, admire Marc Riboud's famous Flower Child, taken during anti-Vietnam war demonstrations. A springboard for various local artists, the museum also gives insight into currently world-renowned photographers. For those who crave strong imagery and historical symbols, as well as the pure pleasure of contemplating snapshots from times gone by, this address may become your new sanctuary.

content.title: Excursion from Toulon to Porquerolles

introduction.small: Set off aboard a shuttle boat to discover the most famous of the Îles d'Or Mediterranean islands. Relaxation and well-being are on the agenda for a day full of emotions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Excursion from Toulon to Porquerolles

paragraphs.text:
During a stay in Toulon, take a day to admire the natural charm of the majestic Porquerolles Island. From the port of Toulon, the journey takes only 30 minutes.
This Natura 2000 listed site, part of the Îles d'Or Mediterranean islands - like Port-Cros and Île du Levant -, is extremely popular for its lush vegetation and many forest trails. Heaven on earth for peace and nature lovers! Once you set foot on the island, you will fall for the captivating charm of its white sandy beaches where the water is eternally turquoise, almost transparent.
At lunchtime, do not hesitate to stop in one of the atoll's many restaurants. Afterwards, head to the town of Carmignac, housing Édouard Carmignac's collection of modern and contemporary art under the island's foundations: an opportunity to gaze at the work of master American and European artists from the 1960s. For a sportier day, many leisure activities are available. From mountain bike rentals to water sports, everything is done for you to have an unforgettable day!

content.title: La Corniche, stunning views of the sea

introduction.small: La Corniche is a Toulon institution, where conviviality and wellness are major values.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Corniche, stunning views of the sea

This 4-star hotel is run by a delightful Anglo-French family who absolutely adore the city of Toulon. With a view of the bay of Le Mourillon and the Fort Saint-Louis, the charming atmosphere of this hotel is punctuated by the sweet life.

This small fishing port is ideal for a family stay during the summer season, especially as it is so close to the beach. It is also very popular year-round with business clientele. The 50 sqm suite can be turned into an office, complete with a meeting room that can accommodate seminars of 25 people. The 19 sqm rooms have terraces overlooking the bay or the city and are appointed elegantly and efficiently, with excellent bedding and old photos on the walls. Not to be missed is the "brunch mania', one Sunday a month.

Recharge your energy with organic juices, homemade pastries, burgers and chips, and selected fruits and vegetables from local producers.

content.title: Hôtel de la Ponche, on top of Saint-Tropez's high walls

introduction.small: In the 1960s, this mythical Saint-Tropez hotel was the cradle of the New Wave movement, which revolutionised French cinema.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hôtel de la Ponche, on top of Saint-Tropez's high walls

paragraphs.text:
The Hôtel de la Ponche, the most intimate of establishments on the Riviera, is probably the only boutique hotel to have been built from a fishermen's bar in the old town.

In 1953, the Hôtel de la Ponche was a kind of summer antenna for Parisian artists and bohemians. Bardot and Roger Vadim stayed here during the filming of the legendary And God Created Woman, as did Romy Schneider, Boris Vian, Juliette Gréco, and other luminaries of the period. Run now by Simone Duckstein, the daughter of the former owners, it maintains a constant attention to detail and a quest for perfection. The charismatic Simone has many anecdotes, but to share them would be to violate the rarity and discretion of the establishment.

In the 22 rooms, as in the bar and restaurant, the atmosphere is refined, and outstanding comfort accompanied by luxurious appointments.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Mas du Langoustier: luxury, calm, and authenticity

Le Mas du Langoustier is beautifully located in the wilderness of Porquerolles, the largest of the three islands facing Hyères. It offers luxurious amenities in a charming and comfortable ambience. The rooms are large, nicely decorated in a Provençal style, with stunning views.

This haven of peace amid the pines and eucalyptus is a place for contemplation and relaxation, with tennis court, heated pool, spa treatments and wellness massages available. The friendly and attentive staff welcomes you to the gastronomic restaurant L'Olivier, or on the terrace for a light lunch.

No cars are allowed - the boat only takes 15-20 minutes, the helicopter even less. Le Mas du Langoustier feels like a Robinson Crusoe adventure, only with added comfort!

content.title: Le Lavandou: exceptional sea riches

introduction.small: The village of Le Lavandou, with its sandy beaches and coves, is a water-sports paradise.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Lavandou: exceptional sea riches

paragraphs.text:
Spread over more than 12 km of coastline, the bay of Le Lavandou harbours well-guarded jewels. Its beautiful seabed attracts diving enthusiasts from the world over, drawn by the rich aquatic life and the clarity of the water. If you are lucky enough, you may even meet dolphins and whales in the area, which is part of the Pelagos sanctuary!

There are also vast sandy beaches dotted with small unsullied and untouched coves to explore. Among them, do not miss the beach of Saint-Clair, a pearl nestled at the foot of pine forests, that enjoys particular climate conditions. Its neighbour, La Grande Plage, despite its name, is smaller, and more secret.

Ideally exposed, Le Lavandou offers the warmth of a sun whose rays envelop you languidly from dawn until the first cool evening breeze.

content.title: Le Chantilly, organic roast chicken straight back to childhood

introduction.small: Le Chantilly inspires relaxation and laziness on the Place Puget, one of the prettiest squares in the pedestrian area of ​​Toulon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Chantilly, organic roast chicken straight back to childhood

paragraphs.text:
Created by Michel Fassino (who was famous for his pastries and a real fan of Raimu as he fought for years for the city to pay proper tribute to the French actor) in the 1940s, this brasserie rivalled the very best Parisian addresses in terms of quality.

The decor is chic, with anise green velvet and gold mouldings, while large picture windows let in the bright light of the South. For those who prefer more privacy, the vintage atmosphere on the mezzanine is very cosy, with a retro feel.

The menu is attractive and promises perfectly cooked fresh food: spiced chicken skewers with mashed sweet and regular potato, salmon and chard lasagne, petits farcis (stuffed tomatoes, peppers and courgettes), chuck steak with house-made mash and a red wine sauce, and organic roast chicken served on vintage plates with an apple and potato mash.

content.title: Le Marais: beach restaurant and the perfect place to party

introduction.small: Le Marais, a must stop on the Var coast, is ideal for watching the sunset over the golden islands.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Marais: beach restaurant and the perfect place to party

paragraphs.text:
With its original design, the Marais has become, in just a few years, the fashionable address of Hyères. A simple Mediterranean menu, with Italian accents, is offered to loyal or passing clientele alike. Whether you come to drink cocktails at the bar-strawberry mojitos, served in a jar-or for dinner, this friendly restaurant has the right formula: large plates to share - antipasti of season vegetables, seafood fritters, truffle burrata and grilled vegetables - in a relaxed atmosphere, with your toes dangling in the sea.

Let yourself be tempted by the house special linguine (cherry tomatoes, mozzarella and pesto), the flambeed risotto sharing dish for two with freshly-grated Parmesan, or skin-on cod, sauce vierge and crushed potatoes. For dessert, the honeyed yoghurt mousse with chocolate chips, fresh fruit and puffed rice is a must. Open all year round, Le Marais hosts regular art openings, exhibitions, ephemeral boutiques, live music concerts, and yoga sessions on the beach.

content.title: La Commanderie de Peyrassol: wine and art

introduction.small: An authentic winery in the middle of a park of majestic sculptures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Commanderie de Peyrassol: wine and art

paragraphs.text:
La Commanderie de Peyrassol is an enchanting place combining tradition and modernity. It offers its guests an exceptional visit to ancient cellars and gardens of rare beauty, where monumental sculptures share pride of place with the century-old vineyards and trees.

In the heart of Provence, in the foothills of the Maures mountains, nestled in a natural amphitheatre, the domain of the Commanderie de Peyrassol is a jewel of the Templars. With 92 hectares of vineyards, 2,500 olive trees, and 350 hectares of hunting and truffle grounds, this winery is among the biggest in the region. If you are a wine lover, this visit is definitely not one to miss. The splendour of the Templar cross is echoed in the amazing contemporary art by Gavin Turk, César, François-Xavier Lalanne and Wim Delvove among others, and the ancient stone cellars are home to flamboyantly modern vats in which superb wines mature.

Throughout the year, Peggy's friendly team welcomes you for wine tastings and winery visits. And if you happen to want to spend the night, the guesthouse awaits!

La Commanderie de Peyrassol

content.title: Chez Lulu: charming restaurant, shop, and ambassador for Italian cuisine

introduction.small: Enjoy a walk in Hyères and discover this small, friendly, and very popular restaurant.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Chez Lulu: charming restaurant, shop, and ambassador for Italian cuisine

Like local insiders, take a seat at Lulu. Despite barely three tables being available inside and a terrace overlooking a pedestrian street crowded on summer evenings, this Italian grocery store turned trattoria is hugely popular among locals. The Italian cuisine is very authentic and of the highest quality with Pugliese linguine, mozzarella and speck-stuffed chicken involtini, cep and gorgonzola gnocchi, lemon ravioli with pancetta, a saffron, artichoke and bottarga risotto, Italian cold cuts and more… The menu changes seasonally and according to market availabilities, for your renewed enjoyment. And if you care to reproduce those sensations at home, you may even leave with a packet of Italian pasta or a bottle of Sicilian olive oil for instance.

The place has been enlarged and the adjoining shop offers Italian aperitifs and live jazz concerts several evenings a month.

content.title: Discover the city's history and passions at Toulon's museums

introduction.small: The National Maritime Museum, the Musée d'Art and the Hôtel des Arts: three great places to discover

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the city's history and passions at Toulon's museums

paragraphs.text:
Near the harbour and the clock tower, the splendid building of the National Maritime Museum, with its monumental gate dating from 1738, is one of the few sites that was not destroyed during the Second World War. Completely renovated, the museum has a rich collection of models, paintings, maps, and prints illustrating the glorious maritime history of Toulon.

Less than 800m away, the Musée d'Art, behind its splendid facade dating from the 19th century, offers an extraordinary collection of more than 3,000 pieces of archaeological objects and masterpieces from a wide panorama of art movements from the 15th to the 20th centuries. Particularly strong are the collections of Provençal artists, especially landscape painters and Fauvists.

The Hôtel des Arts, located a stone's throw away, hosts ambitious temporary exhibitions of various contemporary artists (Joana Vasconcelos, Alain Fleischer, Richard Baquié…). Painting, photography, architecture, and digital arts if you are more a fan of contemporary art, this is a must.

content.title: Old Hyères, city of 7,000 palms

introduction.small: Hyères is a renowned seaside resort where celebrities such as Leo Tolstoy, F. Scott Fitzgerald, Salvador Dalí, and Man Ray came to spend their holidays.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Hyères, city of 7,000 palms

paragraphs.text:
Besides its typical architecture and its streets still marked by medieval ruins, like various doors, towers and the Old Castle, Hyères is turned towards the world of art.

The Villa Noailles, former home of the patron Marie-Laure de Noailles, built by architect Robert Mallet-Stevens in the 1920s and 1930s and now listed as a historical monument, was bought and restored by the city. The mansion now houses an art and architecture centre that puts on various arts events throughout the year, including a festival dedicated to the upcoming figures of the fashion world. Hyères is located in the south of Provence, making it one of the sunniest cities in France. Right off its coast are the three 'Golden Islands': Porquerolles, Port-Cros and Le Levant.

The city itself, and all three of these sublime islands, are not to be missed during your stay.

content.title: Pan Deï Palais, Indian luxury far from prying eyes

Apart from the copper plaque on the carved door, nothing hints at the existence of this quiet place, which has a gorgeous flower garden and a delightful turquoise swimming pool. Canopies, curtains, quilts, kilims, and archways participate in the intimacy of the Oriental decor and the comfort of the 12 rooms and suites.

An exclusive intimacy presides in this corner of paradise by day, making it ideal for a couple or family. But in the evening, from 7:00 p.m. onwards, the bar turns into a lounge and the pool is cleverly converted into a dance floor. The cocktails are delicious (try the Sweet Pan Deï with champagne, lychee puree and Saint-Germain liqueur), and the international wine list very well chosen. Come dinnertime, chef Marco Garfagnini expertly combines Italian cuisine with local influences, bringing diners creations such as saffron arancini with a spicy tuna tartare.

content.title: Les Voiles: stylish hotel five minutes from the beach

introduction.small: Here, it is like home. Les Voiles is a small mansion nestled in a neighbourhood of beautiful 1930s-era villas.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Voiles: stylish hotel five minutes from the beach

The establishment's cosy atmosphere and warm welcome instantly transport you into the world of holidays and wellness.

This sleek and chic boutique hotel is frequented by couples, as well as by businessmen in search of tranquillity. Its 17 refined rooms are named after one of the winners of the Giraglia Cup yacht race, a Tropezian regatta also known as the Rolex Cup. Each room is entirely personalised and offers a particular universe: "single attitude" for solo self-care stays, "business" designed for individuals travelling for work, "discovery" blending comfort and views of the sea, and "pleasure" combining the hotel's very best with a terrace offering a panoramic view that you did not know existed over the Toulon bay… as well as various packs and multiple options.

For breakfast, served on the sun-drenched patio, sheltered by sails, or in the charming lobby, you have the choice of organic fresh juices, homemade cakes, and fair-trade espresso coffee. In the evening, spectacularly well-constructed cocktails are served on the rooftop of the hotel, which has stunning views over the bay of Le Mourillon.

content.title: Opéra de Toulon, the musical heart of the city

introduction.small: To discover local culture and the musical scene of Toulon, head straight to the Opéra de Toulon.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Opéra de Toulon, the musical heart of the city

paragraphs.text:
A historical monument designed by architect Léon Feuchère and inaugurated in 1862, its monumental and neoclassical features include a facade of arches, giant grey and pink colonnades, and a pediment that gives it the look of an ancient sanctuary.

This 'Temple of the Arts', located in the heart of the pedestrian-only city centre, can accommodate up to 1,329 spectators in its luxurious auditorium, with its red velvet and gilt interiors, and sparkling chandeliers. The Opera puts on classic productions like Il Trovatore, La Traviata, Tosca, and Così fan Tutte, as well as masterpieces of French lyrical music and operettas, all performed by world-class singers.

Whatever time of year you enter this august chamber, and regardless of what the program is a show, ballet, or concert you will definitely be in for a memorable evening.

content.title: Le Mourillon: a village within the city

introduction.small: The Mourillon neighbourhood, with its quaint street scenes, is a favourite spot for family strolls in the sun.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Mourillon: a village within the city

paragraphs.text:
Just a bit southeast of Toulon's old port, the Mourillon neighbourhood is its own unique village. Its church, daily market, and small businesses contribute to its picturesque atmosphere.

Facing the sea and the Sainte-Hélène sea baths, filled with beautiful bourgeois mansions, and surrounded by parks and gardens of rare species brought from distant expeditions, Le Mourillon is the chicest and liveliest part of Toulon. The coastline has seven hectares of man-made beaches, a water-sports centre with many activities for athletes of all levels and ages, and a multitude of bars and restaurants.

The wild and less known 'sentier des douaniers' path along the coast will bring you to the pine tree-shaded coves of Cap Brun and Mitre. The authentic fishermen's huts at the water's edge bring a joyful and colourful note to the nautical decor.

content.title: Mount Faron: an incredible panorama

introduction.small: Mount Faron's 584m of white limestone dominate the Toulon harbour.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mount Faron: an incredible panorama

paragraphs.text:
Wherever you are in Toulon, the “lighthouse mountain” watches over you with all its telluric force. Whether accessed by cable car a guaranteed thrill for the entire family or by road, reaching the summit of Mount Faron is always a delight.

The splendour of the panorama is impressive: the city and its large harbour are at your feet, and the coast unfolds all its richness, with its lines of cliffs, fragrant scrubland, forests of Kermes oak and Aleppo pine, brilliant bouquets of broom, and beds of multi-coloured flowers. A site of unique beauty and home to much of the fauna and flora of Provence, the mountain offers a wide variety of outdoor activities, such as hiking day and night, mountain biking, and climbing.

The tourist office organises walks throughout the year, supervised by a tour guide.

content.title: Mayol stadium, a rugby legend

introduction.small: All Toulon follows the RCT, the Rugby Club Toulonnais, one of the biggest rugby clubs in France.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mayol stadium, a rugby legend

paragraphs.text:
Toulon is a great rugby town, and the heart of the city beats to the rhythm of Rugby Club Toulonnais games. Everything happens at Stade Mayol in the old port district.

The stadium is named after an early 20th-century singer, Félix Mayol, a great patron of the club, who signed over his song royalties to help finance the facilities. Inaugurated in March 1920, the stadium, which today seats up to 17,287 spectators, is one of the greatest rugby stadiums in France.

Four times winner of the French championship and three times winner of the European Cup, RCT counts some of the best rugby players in the world. Whatever their level of fame, they are all overwhelmed "getting off the bus", that moment when players walk among supporters for a good 50 metres between the bus and the locker room.

The stadium regularly hosts international matches with touring sides from New Zealand, South Africa, and Australia, and the RCT counts among its players some of the best in the world.

content.title: Saint-Tropez: the treasured jewel of the French Riviera

introduction.small: Jet-set destination, and source of inspiration for Cezanne, Bonnard, and Hockney, ‘St-Trop' is the world's most famous seaport.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Tropez: the treasured jewel of the French Riviera

paragraphs.text:
In any season, the village is a must for sea lovers, history buffs, and art connoisseurs. A spectacular event calendar fills the year with world-class events, making this a favourite destination for families and night owls.

Authenticity is not an empty word in this mythical village, which does not return to its senses until the summer's end. The sun-dappled walls and deserted streets, shaded by bougainvillea, are a delight for the visitor. Far from the crowds in the port, is the city's proud citadel from the 16th century well worth the climb.

Besides its renowned Maritime Museum, it offers exceptional views of the Gulf and the marine cemetery. Down at the harbour, towards the Place des Lices and its Provençal market, is the Musée de l'Annonciade, one of greatest small museums in France, with an impressive collection of contemporary art.

content.title: A piece of paradise in Ramatuelle

introduction.small: A haven for lovers of the Var coast, away from the bustle of Saint-Tropez.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A piece of paradise in Ramatuelle

paragraphs.text:
Not far from Saint-Tropez and its frantic pace, the medieval village of Ramatuelle is a haven of nature and tranquillity, nestled at the top of the buttress of the Paillas hill.

The beauty of the site offers breath-taking landscapes. With its vertical drop of 130 metres, the Ramatuelle hill towers over the beaches of Pampelonne, Cape Camarat, and Cape Taillat. The quintessential heart of the village is an invitation to stroll, where you will discover, at each turn of cobbled and flowery streets, delightful passages, fragrant squares, and churches that have retained all their character. Between the ochre facades and the flowering jasmine and honeysuckle, all your senses will be awakened. It feels good to get lost in the authentic Ramatuelle, where, on Thursdays and Sundays, in its main place of Ormeau, a Provençal market offers colourful spices, fruits, and vegetables grown by local producers. For a family holiday or romantic getaway, Ramatuelle is a corner of paradise between land and sea.

Besides the pleasure of walking through the village, many activities are offered: tennis, golf, horse riding, mountain biking... and, of course, a swim in the sea. Another must is the famous live performance festival in early August: it takes place in the open-air theatre and is always an entertaining affair.
